Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER Enhancing Cybersecurity Education Through a Representational Fluency Model

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cybersecurity experts must possess several abilities: deep technical skills, the capability to recognize and respond to complex and emergent behavior, mastery of using abstractions and principles, the ability to assess risk and handle uncertainty, problem-solving and reasoning skills, and facility in adversarial thinking. Based on cognitive theory, this project will investigate the efficacy of model eliciting activities for developing students' ability to recognize and respond to complex and emergent behavior, and how to handle uncertainty and ambiguity. This project extends the theory of representational fluency, which has been proven to be a powerful tool to effectively teach complex concepts in the field of Science and Mathematics to the cybersecurity domain. The findings from this project will shed light on how representational fluency can shape the cognitive schema and cultivate the cybersecurity mindset.

The goals of this project are to: 1) develop model eliciting educational activities that teach network security related concepts using and translating among multiple representations, 2) investigate students' representational fluency and schema of these concepts, and 3) investigate the relationship of students' development of schema and changes in their cognitive processing and control. While the context for this educational research will be network security and the students will be at the undergraduate level, the theory and framework built through this research should be relevant to other knowledge areas in cybersecurity and applicable to different levels of students and professionals in different settings including university classroom or adult continuous education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the span of three years, more than 200 Undergraduate students majored in Engineering or Technology were recruited in this project to understand how different representations and representational fluencies could impact the learning outcome of entry level cryptography classes. Studies showed that students fluent in math representation outperformed those who are not fluent in math representations. Among students whose dominant representation are not math, those who are not able to translate the same concept from one representation to another have the worst learning outcomes. Study also suggests that language might be the bridge to connect math representation and graphical representation. The project produced and refined four Model-Eliciting-Activities (MEAs) on cryptanalysis, symmetric Keys, RSA, and PKI. These activities were developed to improve student’s ability to express and communicate cryptology knowledge into different forms, such as in graphic, text and math.  Details to be found at: https://va.tech.purdue.edu/cyberFM/

This study also attempted to use fMRI to investigate 1) how human brains react to cryptographic concepts in different representations; 2) what occurred in brains when one representation needs to be translated to another; and 3) how does the reinforcement of representation fluency impact the brain activities. The results showed that each type of representation activated the same part of brains reported by existing cognitive neuroscience studies in Physics and Math. However, the project by itself was not able to prove that exercises in representation fluency can change brain activities due to small sample size and other resource constraints.

The detailed finding of this project can be found in two papers published in ASEE 2016 and LASER workshop 2017, and the lightening talk in ACM SIGITE 2018.
